intro: Rubia cordifolia subsp. hexaphylla, commonly known as the six-leafed rue, is a perennial shrub native to regions of Central Asia and the Caucasus. It is characterized by its aromatic, dark green leaves that are typically six-lobed, giving it its subspecific name. The plant produces small, pale yellow flowers that bloom in early summer, followed by dark blue berries. Its leaves and flowers contain essential oils and have been used in traditional medicine for their antispasmodic and analgesic properties. The plant thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or dry habitats.
